subject: Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Why can t they be represented with written letters? And on the same note, why can t they be represented by sounds? The example you give (I cut it) only
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:

> Your trouble stems from the fact that phonemes cannot be identified
> either with sounds or with written letters, but constitute a third,
> separate level.
>

Why can't they be represented with written letters? And on the same
note, why can't they be represented by sounds? The example you give (I
cut it) only seems to show that a certain sound underwent a change and
and that it did not have a written representation. If we cannot
understand phonomes by sound or by writing, why would they be
phonomes, the smallest unit of language that has distinction?

For the sake of argument let's suppose that I live in a country where
there are no dialects and the language consists of 40 phonomes. Why
couldn't I construct an alphabet that accurately represents them.
